awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Standing, Lying, and Sitting: Restructuring Intermolecular Forces in Molecular Monolayers and Freshman Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Shelley Claridge of Purdue University is supported through a CAREER award by the Supramolecular, Macromolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division to develop bioinspired surface chemistry that tailors electronic properties and solubility of technologically important layered materials. Graphene and other layered materials have the potential to improve applications ranging from high-efficiency solar cells to precision biosensors. Controlling surface chemistry represents a useful means of affecting properties such as conductivity and solubility to help reach these aims. However, in practice this control has been difficult to achieve. Professor Claridge's group takes a bioinspired approach to solving both problems using one of nature's chosen building blocks for controlling interface chemistry:  fat molecules (lipids). The educational component of this program uses campus dining facilities as context-rich learning environments for first-year general chemistry students and the campus community. 
 
The proposed research uses an unconventional self-assembly strategy based on lipids reoriented into a 'sitting' geometry. This strategy provides precise spatial control over layered material surface chemistry from sub-nanometer to micron scales, enabling nanoscale patterning, device and biological applications. The project establishes a framework for designing new amphiphilic surface chemistries based on independent modifications of each piece of the amphiphile. The new surface chemistry simultaneously controls ligand-substrate electronic coupling and ligand-solvent interactions important for material solubility and processability.  For semiconductor nanocrystals, rigorous control of ligand chemistry has proven to be a key enabler in technological applications; establishing similar control over layered material surface chemistry is expected to provide similar benefits. The educational component of the project makes creative use of campus dining facilities as a shared learning environment for students to improve their understanding of intermolecular forces important in proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates, and assesses their understanding using a published instrument based on structure-drawing problems.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:  The significant advances developed within the scope of this grant include the development of a new class of surface chemistry that incorporates complex nanometer-resolution functional patterns below scales achievable with expensive lithographic fabrication processes. The strategy developed takes advantage of chemistry embedded in molecules similar to those that make up biological cell membranes, which represent one of the most complex known examples of functional interfaces. We showed that these molecular-scale surface patterns can be used to direct macroscopic and nanoscopic interfacial wettability, as well as templating adsorption of other molecules, for multifunctional interface design. As part of this project, we also developed methods that enable nanometer-resolution functional patterning to be routinely scaled up to size scales relevant for applications in areas including electronics, energy conversion, and regenerative medicine. These findings open the door to applications that rely on routine nanometer-resolution interfacial patterning, to control wetting, adsorption, and interactions with nanoscale objects including nanocrystals, or microscale objects such as cells.

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to 11 refereed publications, findings of this project have been the topic of 4 granted US Patents and one additional pending US Utility Patent application, pointing to the potentially broad utility and practical impacts of the work. Additionally, this grant supported the development of new food chemistry demonstrations carried out in a large lecture chemistry course, and in undergraduate dining halls, impacting the education of ~600-800 undergraduates annually, and tying chemistry to the world beyond the laboratory. Assessments based on modern chemical education literature were incorporated into student recitation sections, tying into concepts covered by the food chemistry demonstrations, and illustrating increases in student understanding of intermolecular forces, a common source of student misconceptions in general chemistry learning. Additionally, the project supported the research of 11 undergraduate students; 2 are from underrepresented groups and 9 are female. Of the undergraduates whose projects were supported by this grant, 3 have gone on to PhD programs in Chemistry, 1 is still working with the research group, and others have gone on to other advanced degree programs (such as MS in Biomedical Engineering).
